job_title: Adjucnt Instructor in East Providence, RI
pros:
Gaining experience teaching at a well regarded university. 
If you do a good or good enough job they are likely to keep giving you classes. 
Your department chair may be flexible in scheduling your classes.
I declined teaching more classes at the school but it was a decent enough experience that perhaps I would teach another class for them at some point.
cons:
Low pay. 
If you live in Los Angeles it’s a tough commute.
My least favorite body of students that I’ve ever taught, and I’ve taught at quite a few places. Some of the students were great. Most were fine. However quite a few were bratty. Granted I mostly taught freshman, but I found these students to be abnormally entitled and I’ve dealt with wealthy students my entire career. It could just be me but I didn’t gel with the type of students the film school attracts. I actually left and didn’t take any more classes due to the workload combined with difficult students.

pros: Orange is a great location and the campus and buildings look nice on the outside for the most part. Employees are friendly and willing to support and collaborate.
cons:
difficult to get what you want out of the job - promotions, title changes, raises, some flexible work arrangements. Most people I know did not get any of these things when they asked countless times - there is no raise schedule besides COLA. 

Chapman leadership is often out of touch with what students and staff want - they mean well but make the business or best PR decision at every turn - which is usually the opposite of what students, faculty, and staff want. The university functioned without a hiccup while working remotely but they forced almost everyone to come back in July 2021.

review_title: Great if you can find the right group
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Orange, CA
pros: Great place to work if you can find the right group to work in.
cons: There are many self-contained groups at Chapman, some are good, and some are not.

pros: Good 401k match, Orange & campus are beautiful, great tuition reimbursement, health benefits are good and reasonably priced only if you pick high deductible or HMO
cons: Young & immature workforce (depending which department you are in), drama, politics, upper management is out-of-touch with what their staff does & many lack empathy, way too many unproductive meetings and pay is horrible! Chapman has a certain culture, this may differ from department to department. You have to be a certain type of person to fit in here. Also, they want a lot of your free/personal time and expect you to volunteer for numerous events throughout the year. Parking is $370 annually! They don’t tell you this when you interview. Now you all know! Deduct that from your below average salary!

pros: flexible hours to work when you want.
cons: capped maximum hours, so no overtime.

pros: Inclusive, low stress, great benefits
cons: Low pay, no room for growth

review_title: Not enough staff, much work to do
pros: University pays for the staff's monthly insurance premium and almost all of their spouse's as well. Two weeks off (paid!) during winter break. Many staff have been here for 10-20 years and enjoy supporting students.
cons: The staff pay rates are lower than public universities and much lower than what industry pays. New talent typically stays 1-2 years before going elsewhere to make more money. Turnover is high because there has not been enough staff hired to do the support work after the University has continued to grow tremendously. When someone leaves, their position often goes unfilled or is terminated, thus dumping more work on their colleagues (leaving many doing 2-3 jobs each). The marketing dept. has lost more than a dozen people (both fired and quit) since management changed recently.  We have no direction, leadership nor support. It's a toxic, chaotic environment, so look elsewhere if you want to work in marketing.

pros: Fair pay, good at student/work balance
cons: Hard caps on possible hours to work

job_title: Law Student in Huntington Beach, CA
pros: Helpful faculty and career services
cons: More conservative school in OC

pros: Great community with a lot of good people.
cons: Lower pay, but thats just because i dont work many hours

pros: Good colleagues and convenient job

pros: Class sizes are small, students are passionate, bosses are supportive.
cons: Working as an adjunct is never great.

pros: Training grounds for new university staff.
cons: Lack of career growth opportunities, low pay.

pros: Fun environment good classes and social
cons: Needs more social activities, CoVid

pros: Amazingly supportive administration, true camaraderie among faculty, beautiful and comfortable work spaces (on both campuses), and the most updated and functional technology I've ever seen in a classroom. Their educational technology and library support staff are always efficient and effective, and whatever kind of classroom/curriculum support you need, you get.  We earn high-end salaries as FT faculty comparatively across similar programs nationwide, and we have benefits which are incredible, including retirement matching.  Most of all, the President is visible, accessible, and inspires confidence that our primary mission will remain student-centric (never forced to take a back seat to ethics, athletics, a medical enterprise, or research dollars, even as we seek to grow the latter).  Lastly, Sodexo brews the best coffee in town, and their tropical iced tea is delicious - just the icing on the cake!
cons: Disappointed that a disproportionate number of adjunct faculty have the nerve to rate Chapman so low on this site, simply because they don't get benefits. I'd like to know what university (or employer), if any, actually provides benefits to part-timers?

pros: I think the benefits to working at a medium sized university are the employee appreciation and recognition, great access to students and student needs, and that the university is growing constantly. Things are changing all the time and there is something exciting happening almost every day. As someone who has worked here for less than a year, the transition to this job was very smooth and the community welcomed me in immediately. As an employee, I have felt my needs met by the university as an employee when I need help figuring out benefits or similar issues.
cons: Despite the great community, the gaps between the highly paid and the low paid are pretty big. As someone on the lower end of that scale, it is interesting to see the disparities between the administrative staff and others in high power roles at the university. This is the reality of most large companies, though, so it is easy to look past since the employees are treated so well in other ways.

review_title: Chapman perks not worth the poor pay
pros: Location is amazing and its very laid back. Tuition benefits and overall benefits are awesome. You don't have to work hard because they know they don't pay enough and thus you are compensated for the laid back atmosphere.
cons: Technology wise Chapman is light years behind. Everything is manual and out dated. Processes take forever to get implemented and the chain of command is confusing. Chapman pays way less than any other University in the area. They cannot keep people because they do not promote or pay equitable salaries.

job_title: Graphic Designer, Digital Art and Animation in Orange, CA
pros: I worked a number of jobs at Chapman during my time as an undergraduate student here. If you're serious about making some money while here it's totally possible. There are plenty of easy office jobs with very flexible hours, you can work as much as you want really. For more specialized positions that might pertain a bit more to your studies ( for me it was design, film) those are a little more competitive. Still, I wouldn't pass up that AV tech, or Front Desk assistant role, they're fun in their own ways. Most of the time you'll be working with other students and you'll probably get to spend more time with professors depending on your position.
cons: Hourly pay across the board is pretty low. Finding anything higher than $9/hr is pretty tough, but for the amount of work you do it's not bad. For students I think it's a pretty fair compensation considering how flexible the hours and positions are.

review_title: Great place if you hate your life
pros: Health benefits were above average, vacation time was better than industry (although most academic places are), rate of pay is high for academia, but again, it is a private school with very wealthy donors
cons: Micromanagement, poor management of budgets/funding, often try to force hourly employees to work off the clock. Several times my managers forced me to buy office supplies (like coffee creamer) after work and refused to pay for the time or mileage, said it was part of working in a time. Office politics are rampant, if they don't believe you fit in, don't expect to be working there long (I made the mistake once of saying I liked science, science mind you). Upper management is a joke, they are unable to handle issues like lateral aggression. These people are only obsessed with getting more money from students and espousing right-wing agenda whenever possible, and it shows.

job_title: Mail Clerk II in Orange, CA
pros: The benefits and time off are awesome. Pay is good when you start but you get inadequate raises after. Free classes
cons: Management (if you can call it that) is horrible. I worked in the mail room for over 8 years, and the supervisors usually have no clue how to run a department or even communicate effectively. There are a lot of departments that have it much better. If you are work in  a service department you will be treated like garbage, and have no real opportunity to better yourself. There are nice people in every department but not enough to make you feel appreciated. I don't expect anything to be given to me but when you bust your butt a thank you can go a long way. You also have to pay a lot for parking

pros: Tons of truly WONDERFUL people work here.  Serious quality from the President down to the lowest-paid workers.  This school just seems to attract good-hearted people to its leadership and its positions.
cons: But these good people are still frequently swayed or silenced by the vile, cancerous, projecting, underdeveloped, unethical, mean-spirited, straw-man arguing and character-assassinations-in-lieu-of-actual-reasoning Libertines trying to pass themselves off as Liberals who seem to comprise a majority of the faculty.

pros: Benefits are basic, Good matching + for 403B plan, Tuition paid IF your supervisor lets you attend xkAAWA,
cons: The pay is horrible for what is expected of you.  Too many managers.  Too much duplicity and worthless meetings.  The education here is no better than anywhere else.  Do not buy into the exclusive label.  Most of the hype is "smoke and mirrors." Money is wasted on appearances and not funneled into the important aspects of the universities true function.

review_title: The best work-study job I have had to date
pros: I was working part time as a student while in the music program at Chapman University.  My hours were flexible and able to be fitted around my schedule.  The work was simple enough without being exceptionally mindless, and the working conditions were quite acceptable.  I got to work with friends, peers, and professors.
cons: Low wage is the largest con, but it was acceptable and helped me pay for school.  Minimal working hours, so even if I wanted more, there was only so much work to be done per week.

job_title: Marketing Department Employee in Orange, CA
pros: Beautiful campus and facilities are new!
cons: Chapman is like a cult. If you don't fit in, they will push you out. This place has more drama than Hollywood. They believe strongly in the notion of "Chapman family", which means, they like to promote from within instead of hiring more experienced/knowledgeable professionals from the outside. So departments are often supervised by unqualified alumni who will never leave their jobs so you're forever stuck in your position and will never advance. Incompetence is rewarded here as long as you say yes to everything your supervisor tells you. Fortunately, I got out in time to find a better opportunity at a place that values innovation and skills over nepotism.

pros: My fellow coworkers are amazingly skilled, and on the whole, great team players. They adapt quickly and efficiently to the many compounding issues that are thrown at them on a daily basis. Considering the hostile environment, the workforce does an outstanding job.
cons: The upper management staff have created a toxic and hostile work environment ruled by fear tactics. They harshly crush any diversity of thought, so most people keep their heads down and their mouths shut. The Disney Institute recently came in and confirmed that upper management has created a toxic working environment. HR does little to protect employees. There is no room for advancement and no raises. Turn over rate is high.

review_title: Good people but needs some work...
pros: Beautiful campus, lots of things going on in the area, good tuition benefits and retirement matching, good programs at the school, things to do in the area on your lunch or after work.
cons: Salaries are not competitive, HR department does not support conferences and training for them so they aren't well enough equipped to support the staff, Deans aren't provided with management training and many need it because they were solely academic for their careers but now have to supervise employees--academic and non, I saw a lot of promotions for people whose work was sub-par, negatively affecting morale and de-motivating people.

pros: Great resources available to adjunct faculty... take advantage of them!
cons: The school is growing, and it may be hard to find places for your office hours, but be creative and persistent!

pros: There's no tax on the pay (especially if it's work study). The staff and management is is friendly, informative, and helpful. I love that we have the chance to learn programs like persona, and we get to associate with students all over campus; be it a setup for an event or someone just needing to get back into their dorm room.
cons: The pay is only minimum wage, and we're only allowed to work nineteen hours a week as students. Otherwise there's no bad sides to working on campus, it's a great opportunity to learn, grow, and be engaged on campus!

pros:
Several of my co-workers were genuine and kind - I am so glad that I got to know them and that they were there to help me navigate the organization.

Pay is ok - benefits are amazing. Health insurance is unbelievable! The cost is highly subsidized by the University so you can get really great health insurance for a nominal fee. They also have amazing retirement benefits - and they match the contributions you make so it's a no-brainer that you should participate in the plan. The benefits really make the job worth it. They even provide free tuition for employees after a year, and for children of employees, after you've worked at CU for four years your child's tuition (if he/she is accepted) is FREE. Let me say one of the biggest pro's to CU is Jim Doti. Having a chance to meet and work with him was one of the most amazing things I've ever done. He's a visionary and he's a true leader and it will be a sad day for Chapman when he leaves this summer, though Daniele Struppa is awesome too.
cons:
Your experience at CU will depend greatly upon the department in which you work, and quite significantly on your direct supervisor. My department and supervisor were not good so my experience is one that I never care to repeat. However I'd consider returning to CU if I was able to work in a different department with a supervisor who knew what he/she was doing. Other individuals I worked with and got to know had great supervisors and their experience at CU was **way** better than mine. 

You should get to know the culture at Chapman - it's unique and it can be a challenge to fit in  especially in the beginning. The gossip machine at CU is very sturdy... know that everyone, everywhere is listening to what you say and reporting it back to other employees or your supervisor. I'm not the paranoid type, but after working here, I learned that the walls have ears and they aren't reluctant to share what they hear - even if they embellish it or make it up completely. It can feel like you're surrounded by tattle-tails, and, to some degree you are. There are people who will deliberately try to make you look bad so that they look good. And, beware of those who will lie about you to cover their own mistakes - it happens a lot depending on your department. It's a real bummer. 

It's hard to get a foot in the door at CU, so be persistent if it's where you really want to work. If I was rating my experience at CU solely on my department and supervisor, I'd have given it a big fat zero - but because of the friends I made and the other departments which are well run, organized, and have effective supervisors, I'm rating CU higher.

pros: The film school’s rising reputation has put Chapman on the map—great to help build the brand. Freedom to teach courses your way. Smart, respectful students inspire everyday. Top facilities, good benefits and charming old town.
cons: Ridiculously low pay.  $400 annual parking fee.  Crazy amount of red tape and lame computer technology. Politically motivated management.

review_title: A great learning and entry level job experience.
pros: I loved my time there. The atmosphere was great and so were the coworkers. Easily and quickly promoted as long as you're willing to put in the hard work. They are great at working with your schedule and will give time off if requested far enough in advance. I learned more at this job then I did in my actual editing classes at school.
cons: My supervisors were awesome but our overall boss could be a little questionable at times. Seems like she would lay people off for no reason.

pros: A great place to work for self-motivated individuals. There is little micro-management within the loans department, but managers are always there to answer your questions.
cons: Due to the small size of the office it may become difficult to move up, but when a position does open up, they tend to hire from within.

pros: Resident Advisors have a chance to be autonomous while working with a team of creative, excited professionals. Lots of experience in program planning, student outreach, and diversity training.
cons: One big happy family always has its cliques.

pros: Good pay and benefits.  Fun social outings, lots of free lunches.  Famous guest speakers, a great Film School, and Performing Arts Center.
cons: Constant backstabbing in the 18 years that I worked under Facilities and Campus Planning.  Best place I ever worked as far as pay; worst place I ever worked as far as the people.  To get rid of people they didn't like, they rewrote the job descrption and told you that you weren't qualified.  If you want to work for a place that is slimier than any corporate environment, maybe you'd like it here (if you are evil).

pros: The autonomy and flexibility they give you with the work and your schedule is extremely nice. They treat you like a professional and completely understand if you have another job. They grant you the flexibility to make your work schedule congruent with that job.
cons: You are limited to 19 hours per week which is really unfortunate. I could be achieving a lot more in my job with more allotted time.

review_title: Wonderful way to build experience, but not sustain a career
pros: Tight knit community. Lots of opportunities to create programming and access to leadership.
cons: Low pay. Not a well-known university with staff hires having little or no experience in education or non-profit.

review_title: Collaborative culture, flexible and empathetic, encourages growth.
pros: Staff get reasonable tuition remission, encouraged to take on new initiatives, good work/life balance.  My department always strives to improve and we work towards that common goal.  Being a university with a Christian background and some prominent conservative faculty, the staff culture is pretty liberal and relaxed.
cons: Things get done slower than they do in the corporate world (from which I came).

pros: There are a lot of reasons including all of the events that they hold on-campus and the general attitude of the campus - everyone is friendly.
cons: The pay is not always the most competitive or the greatest because it is a job in education after all.

review_title: Great place to work! Very flexible schedule for graduate students.
pros: Great culture.  The university really cares about its students'  well-being and education and the university offers a lot of opportunities for its students to obtain employment.
cons: I really can't think of anything.  Perhaps, higher pay (I received 12 per hour) but I know that this is a typical pay range for graduate students...

pros: Very flexible around work schedule
cons: Too lenient on some of the students who didn't take the job seriously

pros: Pay was good, fun parties, great benefits.  Got a chance to work with a large variety of constituencies.  Good President.
cons: I worked in a dept that was constantly stabbing everyone in the back.  People got away with treating people horribly because they were the boss's friend.

review_title: Nothing but good things to say!
pros:
-Supportive work environment
-Competitive pay and great benefits
-Beautiful place to work at an extremely up-and-coming campus
cons: -Being a small liberal arts school, there seems to be less of an availability for jobs in general

job_title: Adjunct Professor, Law in Orange, CA
pros: Great support, great staff and work with wonderful colleagues. Students are bright and ready to learn. Good facilities and decent pay.
cons: None. I enjoyed every aspect of the job. I would teach all year round if they allowed me to do so. I suppose the pay is not the greatest but it was just a part time gig.

pros: There is a high sense of community, and I developed a greater sense of pride for my university. I was also afforded a great amount of trust and responsibility as a student assistant.
cons: As a smaller university, there were relatively fewer positions available. There was also a high rate of turnover while I was there as well.

pros: This school is top-notch in every area - especially in the English Department. The professors are experts in their respective fields, they are helpful, kind and make the experience a positive, yet challenging one. Tutoring other students is enjoyable and a learning experience for both.
cons: Not enough clients; slow at times but still got paid

job_title: Campus Tour Guide in Orange, CA
pros: Extremely pleasant student workforce. The other student hires are really flexible and easy to work with. Additionally the full time staff is very accommodating when it comes to scheduling around classes/conflicts.
cons: The office can get a bit hectic during decision season. However that’s nothing that I wouldn’t expect from a university of Chapman’s size.

pros: There are some very, bright and talented students and amazing faculty, and it was a joy to serve them in the work that they do.
cons: HR is not employee-centric. Everything is political. Management is largely incompetent.

pros: Great coworkers, wonderful location, work is relatively easy, good retirement matching plan
cons: Little/no room for advancement within your division, no professional development, other departments can be territorial and unhelpful, compensation isn't very good given the cost of living in Orange County

job_title: Assistant Director of Admission in Orange, CA
pros: Good manager makes all the difference
cons: Does not have progressive approach to work models. Working remotely, flex days, or other possibilities do not appear to be a consideration for staff.

review_title: Working with students and colleagues is most rewarding.
pros:
Beautiful campus
Easy to get time off
Great benefits and retirement plan
Great student population
Great coworkers
You get to dabble in as many different areas that you want.
cons:
Constantly asked to do more without compensation for the additional responsibilities.
Difficult to maintain a work-life balance as a Resident Director.

pros: Pull down boards with a prestigious atmosphere.
cons: Very crammed drive to the campus. Also, I was recruited by Chapman's Business college due to my experience teaching Business calculus in Cal Poly, Pomona. I am primarily a mathematician and it seemed my commission emphasized more financial analysis than sheer mathematics.

pros:
Great community and staff
Management is normally good about communication
cons:
Small facilities 
Lots of hoops to jump through if you want to make any progress or changes. Necessary to have lots of communication with management.

pros: People care about one another and have patience for each other
cons: everyone is overworked- as the university grows there needs to be investment in talent across the board.

review_title: Computational Science: Excellent Education, Excellent Work Place
pros: Diversity and understanding. This institution provides real experience for those studying computational science while earning your degree....whatever that may be.
cons: No real cons yet, have had the best experience working at this place.

review_title: Great experience as a student worker
pros: make connections, great work environment, working towards improving things to make Chapman better which is exciting, accommodating to student needs with tests, clubs, job fairs etc.
cons: lots of hours as a student, could probably take PTO but seems discouraged as a student

review_title: Something to put on the resume
pros:
"Administrative assistant" tends to look good on the resume to employers now.
Gave me a little money to help me pay my way through college.
cons:
Very boring, tedious, and LONELY work. 
Minimum wage pay.

pros: Most teams at chapman are incredibly motivated. Each department is always trying to expand and be better. The school is small, which is nice and creates a homey feel.
cons:
They don't always give teachers of color full time jobs here
Very conservative area

pros: Gorgeous campus! People are friendly.
cons: Administration pushes their own agenda. Only get to keep your job if you are the right personality and "are needed to support their agenda".

job_title: Help Desk Support in Orange, CA
pros: The benefits and opportunity for training are ok.
cons: Employees pay for parking, too many meetings which could be done in email, and no clear direction from technology.

review_title: A great place to continually grow and expand
pros: I really enjoy working at Chapman there is a great family style vibe.  Very friendly and I love being able to work with students on a daily basis.
cons: Pay could be a little higher

pros: benefits and time-off is ok
cons: Mobility feels like a farce because they pay so far below market.

job_title: Student Library Worker in Orange, CA
pros: You don't have to go far when going to work right after class. Friendly employers willing to give first time job experience.
cons: The only con for me was the low paying salery ($8/hour) and very few hours available to work.

pros: Great benefits! Worked full-time while pursuing my Masters Degree which allowed me to receive a very generous tuition discount. Great 401K match, health benefits are standard.
cons: Not a lot of room for growth. Starting salary was on the lower end with minimal raises.

review_title: Top University pays poverty wages to faculty
pros: Facilities are premier quality, with equipment and rooms constantly being remodeled and upgraded
cons: Pay is equal to poverty wage with no room for growth

pros: Good compensation, especially as a student. Unique and fulfilling job to have while in college helping and mentoring peers.
cons: Some disorganization within management, but that could be expected from the inevitable high turnover of direct supervisors year-to-year.

pros: Own room, free room and board
cons: Work more hours than contracted for without additional compensation and some people in the same position do not have to do the same amount of work

pros:
- Excellent benefits
- Facilities are new
- Majority of the staff are great to work with
cons:
- Everything moves very slowly through upper administration
- Staff do not feel that they are regarded as essential
- Very little transperancy

pros: Good salary. Facilities are good and equipped. Prompt help from other faculty.
cons: No space for adjunct office and hard to find spaces to hold office hours otherwise. Little help with admin work (printing, etc)

pros: Good people, up to date faculty, nice staff, great students.
cons: slow to adapt to change (except for virtual reality, they jumped on that!)

job_title: Public Safety Officer in Anaheim, CA
pros: Good fellow employees, work conditions are very user friendly, benefits are very good.

job_title: Guest Relations Coordinator in Tustin, CA
pros:
- Great transparency between management and employees.

pros: nice co-workers, nice facilities, and a nice area if you work on the Orange campus
cons: New buildings are built without user input, so usually end up with issues. Typical academic drama exists among faculty and upper admin.

pros: relaxed and easygoing approach to work

pros: They were VERY helpful when I first started working there.  Orientation, welcome meetings... this University is so much cleaner than the one I attended...

review_title: Can't have a better part time job than this.
pros:
- treat employees well

pros: Great leadership. excellent facilities, generous benefits.  An up and coming university
cons: Pay is high for a nonprofit but not quite up to the level of a for-profit.

pros: Great work life balance, and amazing benefits. High energy campus and great students/faculty/staff/administration. Would highly recommend working here.

pros: Loved the school as I was a student as well, worked with great people, flexible schedule
